Haydon, who was described as the ''perfect'' candidate for the artificial heart when he received it Feb. 17, suffered a stroke late Monday night but made ''a dramatic recovery'' in the hours thereafter, his doctors said yesterday. Mr. Haydon, a 58-year-old retired factory worker who became the third recipient of a permanent artificial heart, remains in critical condition at Humana Hospital Audubon in Louisville. Stroke has been a constant concern in the artificial heart program. Doctors said they still planned to press on with the program and that it was still too soon to know whether the problem could be overcome.

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE of the earliest lessons children are taught about socially acceptable behavior is that there is a proper time and place for the elimination of body wastes. Somewhere between the ages of 2 and 3, most children learn to control elimination most of the time. While occasional accidents are common and accepted in early childhood, beyond the preschool years incontinence is nearly always cause for humiliation and distress. Eight to 10 million Americans, most of them adults, face this distress daily. They suffer from what medical experts call bladder incontinence, the inability to prevent the release of urine at inappropriate times. Rather than risk public disgrace, many people, children and young adults among them, become social recluses. For the elderly, incontinence is often the symptom that exhausts their family's ability to cope; the aged relative may be placed in a nursing home, where untreated incontinence adds significantly to the cost of care. Many people with the problem, young and old alike, are too embarrassed to mention it to their physicians. If and when they do, the doctor, who may also be embarrassed in addition to being unfamiliar with the problem, may dismiss the patient's complaint without much investigation. Among the elderly, the situation is even worse, because so many people, doctors included, incorrectly think incontinence is a normal and uncorrectable consequence of age and illness.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal officials announced today that they were taking emergency action to ban a drug widely known as Ecstasy, saying that abuse of the drug had become a nationwide problem. The ban on use of the drug, formally known as MDMA, will take effect July 1, said John C. Lawn, Acting Administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration. Ecstasy, whose scientific name is 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine. will continue to undergo tests while the emergency ban remains in effect for one year. Some psychotherapists maintain that the drug creates a feeling of well-being in patients, making them more receptive to treatment.
